James Coombs v. Anna Parker and Benjamin Coombs. Where one on selling land, takes notes for the purchase money, with personal security, and afterward, in pursuance of the contract of sale, executes a deed for the premises, by which the vendor’s lien is destroyed, the surety upon the notes is not thereby discharged. This is a bill in chancery, reserved in Clermont county. The bill alleges that Benjamin Coombs purchased a tract of land of Anna Parker on credit, and received a title-bond conditioned for a conveyance when Coombs should pay the purchase money. That to secure the purchase money, Coombs executed certain promissory notes in which complainant joined as security, and on which she has commenced suit. The bill further states, that without complainant’s knowledge the respondents made a new arrangement for the payment of the purchase money, by which she took up the title-bond and gave to Coombs a deed in fee, acknowledging the receipt of the purchase money, and took a mortgage on the land to secure the same, which mortgage^ by an arrangement made without complainant’s consent with said Benjamin Coombs, was not put on *290record in time to secure the lien against other claims, which were intermediately acquired, and have exhausted the mortgaged premises. These acts are claimed to be sufficient to work the complainant’s discharge as a surety, etc. An injunction was obtained which was dissolved on the hearing upon bill and answer, and the bill dismissed in the court of common pleas, from which an appeal was taken to this court. The answer of Anna Parker, which was called for under oath, admits the sale and the taking of the notes ; says that the title-bond is lost, etc., but that it was conditioned that she should convey to said Benjamin Coombs the land in twelve months from its date. Says that when she contracted she did not rely on a lien upon the land for the purchase money, but took Benjamin Coombs’s note, with complainant as surety for that purpose ; denies that there was ever any understanding that she was to hold the legal title as security till the purchase money was paid, but she relied solely on the personal security. That more than a year after the date of the bond, she executed the conveyance and took the mortgage on the representation and agreement of Benjamin Coombs that he could sell the land and pay her, and if not, that he would surrender and cancel the deed, but he deceived her, put his deed on record, mortgaged the land, etc., and as she believes, the complainant, who is Benjamin Coombs’s brother, knew something about it. She admits the proceedings whereby she has lost all claim upon the land as vendor or mortgagee. John Jolliffe, for complainant, cited the following authori- ■ ties :

Mayham v. Coombs, 14 Ohio Rep. 426; Com. Bank Lake Erie v. Western Reserve Bank et al., 11 Ohio Rep. 444; Dixon et al. v. Ewing’s Adm’r, 3 Ohio Rep. 280; Farmers’ Bank of Canton v. Raynolds, 13 Ohio Rep. 104; Clinton Bank of Columbus v. Ayres et al., 16 Ohio Rep. 482; 13 Verm. Rep. 315; 7 Miss. Rep. 497; 9 Watts & Sarg. Rep. 36.

*291Gholson & Miner, and J. W. Lowe, for the defendant, Anna Parker, cited the following authorities:

Neimcewicz v. Ghan, 3 Paige’s Rep. 651; Grafton Bank v. Kent, 4 New Hamp. Rep. 221; Bangs v. Strong, 10 Paige’s Rep. 16; Mohawk Bank v. Van Horne, 7 Wend. Rep. 117; Pring v. Clarkson, 1 Barn. & Cress. Rep. 14; 1 Story’s Eq. Jur. 4th Ed. 568; Macdonald v. Bell, 3 E. T. Moore’s Rep. 315, 332; Cassel v. Butler, 2 Sim. & Stu. Rep. 457; Farmers’ Bank of Canton v. Raynolds; 13 Ohio Rep. 84; Hayes v. Ward, 4 Johns. Ch. Rep. 180; 1 Story’s Eq. Jur. sec. 499, a, b, c, d; 11 Eng. Ch. Rep. 128; Brush v. Kingsley, 14 Ohio. Rep. 20; 8 Eng. Ch. Rep. 338 ; Henley v. Stemmons, 4 B. Monroe’s Rep. 131; Burk v. Chrisman, 3 B. Monroe’s Rep. 50; Woodward v. Clegge, 8 Ala. Rep. 317.

Birchard, C. J.

This case standing upon bill and answer under oath, the answer must be taken as true so far as it responds to the bill. The inquiry then is, do the facts thus stated show that the complainant should be released from the payment of these notes ? The answer 'avers that Mrs. Parker had made an engagement to convey the land on a particular day, and that she relied at the making of the contract upon the personal security taken to secure the purchase money, and not on the land or on the vendor’s lien. That there was no agreement or understanding that she should look to any thing but to said personal security, yet that she was deceived and cheated out of her title by the complainant’s brother, her co-defendant. This ■case so made by the answer, is in its material features quite variant from the case made by the bill, and to which the arguments of complainant’s counsel are mostly applicable. As the case stands, there is no act done by Anna Parker which should release James Coojnbs, unless it is the conveyance to Benjamin before the payment of the purchase money. But that she avers was in pursuance of her contract. Is there any rule of equity which requires us to hold this act a release of the personal secu*292rity of James ? The object in taking him as security, was that the estate might pass by deed into the hands of the vendor unincumbered and discharged of the vendor’s lien. It was for that reason only that Mrs. Parker’s claim for the purchase money was postponed to Mayham’s mortgage. 14 Ohio Rep. 437.

It ought not then to be held that the mere conveying of the land, according to the written contract,-is a discharge of the surety. Mrs. Parker had a right to convey, nay, was bound to-tender the deed on the day mentioned in the title-bond. True, she might have retained it for her own security until she received payment, but she was not bound to do so. She had made no contract to that effect, and all that James Coombs could require of her in equity was, that she should conduct honestly toward both himself and his principal; and honesty required from her a- tender of the deed at the time agreed upon, and from-Benjamin Coombs and the complainant a like tender to her of the sums due upon the notes. The power which she had of retaining the possession of the deed of conveyance after tender until actual payment of the purchase money, was a mere incident to the contract, which the law permitted, and is in no-sense to be regarded as a colla-tdral security, which must be retained at the hazard of releasing sureties. Again, it is urged that complainant ought to be discharged.on the ground of negligence in not placing upon record the mortgage. We think her acts in this respect are sufficiently explained by her answer. She was deceived by the bad conduct of complainant’s brother, and by means of his fraud was induced, greatly to her own prejudice, to deliver him a deed for one purpose which' he used for another. If she had succeeded in securing her claim by the means of the mortgage, and had then through negligence lost the security, she would also have lost all equitable claim upon complainant. But she failed in securing any thing by the mortgage. That was her misfortune, not her fault. The statute which requires a mortgage deed to be left for record before it can take effect, with the aid of B. Coombs in this case, effectually prevented Mrs. Parker from obtaining a security of any *293value. So that if complainant is to be released for the neglect to record in time, he is released not because his adversary parted with or destroyed a mortgage security, which she ought to have held for his benefit, but because she was cheated by his principal, and could get no such security to part with.

Bill dismissed. ■.
